candidates.title: Correct publish pipeline for multi-package publish in workspace

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
The publish pipeline was incorrectly specified. We should be using the ```-p``` flag to indicate the package within the workspace to publish. See [docs](https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/commands/cargo-publish.html)

Also needed to add the ability to "clone" a ```Directory<S>``` for downstream usage (with async move patterns). A clone of the directory will simply be a pointer to the same storage layer, but with an independent transaction (if one is present at all).


candidates.title: Integration tests

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
Added integration tests against 2 backing database structures

1. MySQL
2. In-memory database

These tests test the full end-to-end functionality of the directory of AKD from 

1. Publish
2. Lookup proof & verify
3. History proof & verify
4. Audit proof & verify

MySQL tests however won't run in the CI without adding docker support, but they will be auto-skipped if the docker container is not running or can't be found

candidates.title: Reorganize the repository structure

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
In order to better manage dependencies and minimal importing, this PR breaks apart the repository into 2 library crates and 1 binary crate linked in a single workspace.

Crates in project:
1. The base "AKD" library in the ```akd``` folder.
2. The MySQL specific data-layer implementation for an AKD in the ```akd_mysql``` folder, becoming a new crate "akd_mysql"
3. The POC application ("akd_app") in the ```poc``` folder. 

By using a common workspace, we can simplify the commands needed to be run by cargo to interactively test with the POC app (i.e. we can run ```cargo run``` from the directory root without having to go into the ```poc``` folder). Since it's the only _binary_, cargo will always run the POC without need for additional arguments.

```akd_mysql``` and ```akd_app``` both reference ```akd``` in their ```Cargo.toml``` files by filepath reference, so they're always up to date. Additionally Rust will detect breaks across all crates without having to navigate to different folders/solutions/etc. ```cargo fmt``` and ```cargo clippy``` will run across all crates with a single call as well to make sure we're up-to date. All unit tests, in all crates will be run with a single ```cargo test``` call.

With this breakapart, we've removed ```mysql_async```, ```evmap```, ```lazy_static```, and ```rayon``` as dependencies of the base ```akd``` crate so external users import less code that may not be relevant. Anyone who wants a MySQL connection can simply import ```akd_mysql``` on top of ```akd``` and will have a full implementation of a MySQL database connector.

Also updated docs & added debugging launch.json for VSCode with use of lldb.

Lastly, removed V1Storage in favor of a single Storage trait (which is the renamed trait from V2Storage) since no one had yet implemented V1, we didn't need the backwards compatibility. This required rewriting the cached in-memory database, which is better anyways since now it doesn't rely on a shared static instance of anything. Meaning we can instantiate multiple cache'd databases in a single process safely.

candidates.title: Multi-row insert performance with MySQL & storage layer cleanups

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
Changes: 
1. Remove unused storage-layer operations
2. Performance enhancements with batch-insert in MySQL
3. Db tuning POC command, where the multi-row parallel insert number is adjustable.
4. Parallelize serialization operations in batches with ```rayon``` packages (version matches internal infra version)

candidates.title: Batch user information retrieval + disabling cache cleaning during a transaction

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
This PR contains more IO improvements where we disable cache-cleaning during a transaction. The logic behind this is that we're doing high IO work and will likely be re-reading a lot of nodes frequently (especially at the higher levels of the tree), that we shouldn't clear the cache until the transaction is completed.

+ Migrated to a pure v2 storage impl in-memory database.

+ Batch retrieval of value state version information so with a single db query we can retrieve all user versions in a publish operation. The large the batch size, the more performant this will be (i.e. for 100K users it's 1 op vs 100K ops).

candidates.title: Bug fixes and adjustments for cache management

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
Currently performance is a batch of 100,000 takes approximately 40 minutes on a relatively fresh tree. That is expected to degrade as the tree grows, since compression will be minimized.

Also found the race condition with locks which was causing us to deadlock on cache cleaning

Additionally removed the dev dependency on artix_rt for testing (using tokio::test directly)

candidates.title: Pass down storage trait through low-level functions

labels.name: CLA Signed
labels.description: This label is managed by the Facebook bot. Authors need to sign the CLA before a PR can be reviewed.

candidates.body:
This ensures that the lower-level APIs (append_only_zks, history_tree_node) use the storage trait passed down in order to store things. However, for tests, local storage (through the node's state_map struct) is still used because I couldn't get this to work nicely for tests.

This way, if we need to store things per-node, we can just call get_state_map and set_state_map.
